channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: The future is quantum: universities look to train engineers for an emerging industry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03511-7

With quantum technologies heading for the mainstream, undergraduate courses are preparing the workforce of the future.
item.dc:title: The future is quantum: universities look to train engineers for an emerging industry
item.dc:creator: Sophia Chen

item.title: Citizen scientists find a rarity: an asteroid trying to be a comet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03399-3

An object that orbits the Sun beyond the main asteroid belt and occasionally sports a tail is spotted in archival images.
item.dc:title: Citizen scientists find a rarity: an asteroid trying to be a comet

item.title: AI that reads brain scans shows promise for finding Alzheimer’s genes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03482-9

Machine-learning approach detects Alzheimer’s disease with an accuracy of more than 90% — a potential boon for clinicians and scientists developing treatments.
item.dc:title: AI that reads brain scans shows promise for finding Alzheimer’s genes
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Colombia begins sterilizing its invasive hippos: what scientists think
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03516-2

Environment ministry launches programme that also includes exporting and euthanizing the animals, which threaten the country’s biodiversity.
item.dc:title: Colombia begins sterilizing its invasive hippos: what scientists think
item.dc:creator: Luke Taylor

item.title: Earth just had its hottest year on record — climate change is to blame
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03523-3

Around 7.3 billion people faced temperatures strongly influenced by global warming over the past year.
item.dc:title: Earth just had its hottest year on record — climate change is to blame
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Why is Delhi’s air pollution so bad right now?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03517-1

The post-monsoon season creates ideal conditions for air pollution to accumulate in the Indian megacity.
item.dc:title: Why is Delhi’s air pollution so bad right now?
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: The unexpected outcomes of artist-scientist collaborations
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 10 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03390-y

Artists love working with scientists, and when they do it can unlock new perspectives for research.
item.dc:title: The unexpected outcomes of artist-scientist collaborations
item.dc:creator: Julie Gould

item.title: Author Correction: Plastic pollution on the world’s coral reefs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06796-w

Author Correction: Plastic pollution on the world’s coral reefs
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Plastic pollution on the world’s coral reefs
item.dc:creator: Hudson T. Pinheiro

item.title: Flashy molecules decode a polymer’s lengthening chain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03497-2

A fluorescence-imaging method can be used to identify the sequence of molecular building blocks in a polymer.
item.dc:title: Flashy molecules decode a polymer’s lengthening chain

item.title: One brain area helps you to enjoy a joke — but another helps you to get it
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03400-z

Seinfeld episodes help scientists to distinguish between the brain regions involved in understanding and appreciating humour.
item.dc:title: One brain area helps you to enjoy a joke — but another helps you to get it

item.title: This hybrid baby monkey is made of cells from two embryos
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03473-w

The work paves the way for scientists to use chimeric primates to study human diseases.
item.dc:title: This hybrid baby monkey is made of cells from two embryos
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Researcher resignations from UKRI mount amid Israel–Hamas row
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03492-7

Academics are furious that the funder complied with a demand from the government to suspend an advisory panel over comments made about the conflict.
item.dc:title: Researcher resignations from UKRI mount amid Israel–Hamas row
item.dc:creator: Carissa Wong

item.title: Tropical diseases move north
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03476-7

As Earth warms, the creatures that spread neglected tropical diseases are gaining a foothold in Europe. Wealthy countries must prepare themselves for more cases.
item.dc:title: Tropical diseases move north
item.dc:creator: Claire Ainsworth

item.title: How to make research reproducible: psychology protocol gives 86% success rate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 09 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03486-5

Four groups in the field of experimental psychology successfully replicate each other’s work by following best practices.
item.dc:title: How to make research reproducible: psychology protocol gives 86% success rate
item.dc:creator: David Adam

item.title: Retraction Note: Cross-HLA targeting of intracellular oncoproteins with peptide-centric CARs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06731-z

Retraction Note: Cross-HLA targeting of intracellular oncoproteins with peptide-centric CARs
item.dc:title: Retraction Note: Cross-HLA targeting of intracellular oncoproteins with peptide-centric CARs

item.title: Fastest-rising nations look to solidify research gains
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03442-3

India–US partnerships heat up, as China contemplates rebuilding links with the West.
item.dc:title: Fastest-rising nations look to solidify research gains
item.dc:creator: Bec Crew

item.title: A guide to the Nature Index
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03447-y

A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.
item.dc:title: A guide to the Nature Index

item.title: Role play with large language models
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06647-8

By casting large-language-model-based dialogue-agent behaviour in terms of role play, it is possible to describe dialogue-agent behaviour such as (apparent) deception and (apparent) self-awareness without misleadingly ascribing human characteristics to the models.
item.dc:title: Role play with large language models
item.dc:creator: Murray Shanahan
Kyle McDonell
Laria Reynolds

item.title: Phosphorus-bearing molecules PO and PN at the edge of the Galaxy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06616-1

We report the presence of gas-phase phosphorous at the edge of the Galaxy and suggest it is produced by neutron-capture processes in lower mass asymptotic giant branch stars.
item.dc:title: Phosphorus-bearing molecules PO and PN at the edge of the Galaxy
item.dc:creator: L. A. Koelemay
K. R. Gold
L. M. Ziurys

item.title: Tuning sterol extraction kinetics yields a renal-sparing polyene antifungal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06710-4

A study reports the development of a structural derivative of amphotericin B with broad antifungal activity in mice but without the renal toxicity associated with amphotericin B.
item.dc:title: Tuning sterol extraction kinetics yields a renal-sparing polyene antifungal
item.dc:creator: Arun Maji

item.title: Neural landscape diffusion resolves conflicts between needs across time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06715-z

Behavioural and electrophysiological studies in simultaneously thirsty and hungry mice reveal a neural basis for resolving conflicts between needs, in which choices are guided by a persistent and distributed neural goal state that undergoes spontaneous transitions between goals.
item.dc:title: Neural landscape diffusion resolves conflicts between needs across time
item.dc:creator: Ethan B. Richman
Nicole Ticea
William E. Allen
Karl Deisseroth
Liqun Luo

item.title: Targeting of intracellular oncoproteins with peptide-centric CARs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06706-0

Peptide-centric chimeric antigen receptors (PC-CARs) provide a platform to address the challenges involved in targeting intracellular oncoproteins, and PC-CARs based on the neuroblastoma-dependency gene PHOX2B induce elimination of aggressive tumors.
item.dc:title: Targeting of intracellular oncoproteins with peptide-centric CARs
item.dc:creator: Mark Yarmarkovich

item.title: Functional neuroimaging as a catalyst for integrated neuroscience
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06670-9

This Perspective reviews successful applications of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) and presents a case for fMRI as a central hub on which to integrate the dispersed subfields of systems, cognitive, computational and clinical neuroscience.
item.dc:title: Functional neuroimaging as a catalyst for integrated neuroscience
item.dc:creator: Emily S. Finn
Russell A. Poldrack
James M. Shine

item.title: m<sup>1</sup>A in CAG repeat RNA binds to TDP-43 and induces neurodegeneration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06701-5

TDP-43 binds to N1-methyladenosine on CAG repeat RNA, resulting in the formation of gel-like TDP-43 aggregates in the cytoplasm that resemble those observed in neurological disease pathology.
item.dc:title: m<sup>1</sup>A in CAG repeat RNA binds to TDP-43 and induces neurodegeneration
item.dc:creator: Yuxiang Sun
Hui Dai
Xiaoxia Dai
Jiekai Yin

Xiaochuan Liu

Nancy M. Bonini
X. William Yang

Yinsheng Wang

item.title: Three-dimensional flat bands in pyrochlore metal CaNi<sub>2</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06640-1

Angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy of CaNi2 shows a band with vanishing dispersion across the full 3D Brillouin zone that is identified with the pyrochlore flat band as well as two additional flat bands that arise from multi-orbital interference of Ni d-electrons.
item.dc:title: Three-dimensional flat bands in pyrochlore metal CaNi<sub>2</sub>
item.dc:creator: Joshua P. Wakefield

item.title: Observing the primary steps of ion solvation in helium droplets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06593-5

The initial steps of the ion solvation process are observed for the solvation of a single sodium ion in liquid helium, opening possibilities for benchmarking theoretical descriptions of ion solvation.
item.dc:title: Observing the primary steps of ion solvation in helium droplets
item.dc:creator: Simon H. Albrechtsen
Constant A. Schouder
Alberto Viñas Muñoz
Jeppe K. Christensen
Christian Engelbrecht Petersen
Martí Pi
Manuel Barranco
Henrik Stapelfeldt

item.title: Latent human herpesvirus 6 is reactivated in CAR T cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06704-2

Genomics analyses reveal that in vitro culture of CAR T cells can lead to reactivation of a latent herpesvirus, which might be involved in complications in patients receiving associated cell therapies.
item.dc:title: Latent human herpesvirus 6 is reactivated in CAR T cells
item.dc:creator: Caleb A. Lareau
Yajie Yin
Katie Maurer
Katalin D. Sandor

item.title: Single-molecule dynamics show a transient lipopolysaccharide transport bridge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06709-x

As well as being the substrate for the lipopolysaccharide transport protein complex comprising LptA–G, lipopolysaccharide binding to Lpt proteins promotes their assembly into a bridge linking the inner and outer membranes of Gram-negative bacteria.
item.dc:title: Single-molecule dynamics show a transient lipopolysaccharide transport bridge
item.dc:creator: Lisa Törk
Caitlin B. Moffatt
Thomas G. Bernhardt
Ethan C. Garner
Daniel Kahne

item.title: Asymmetric distribution of parental H3K9me3 in S phase silences L1 elements
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06711-3

The epigenetic modification H3K9me3 is asymmetrically partitioned at long interspersed nuclear element retrotransposons for their silencing in S phase, a newly discovered mechanism that is mediated by the HUSH complex and the DNA polymerase Pol ε.
item.dc:title: Asymmetric distribution of parental H3K9me3 in S phase silences L1 elements
item.dc:creator: Zhiming Li
Shoufu Duan
Xu Hua
Xiaowei Xu
Yinglu Li
Demis Menolfi
Hui Zhou
Chao Lu
Shan Zha
Stephen P. Goff
Zhiguo Zhang

item.title: Plant carbonic anhydrase-like enzymes in neuroactive alkaloid biosynthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06716-y

We show how neuroactive alkaloids from clubmosses are biosynthesized, which reveals an unexpected role for carbonic anhydrase-like enzymes in alkaloid scaffold formation.
item.dc:title: Plant carbonic anhydrase-like enzymes in neuroactive alkaloid biosynthesis
item.dc:creator: Ryan S. Nett
Yaereen Dho
Chun Tsai
Daria Passow
Jaime Martinez Grundman
Yun-Yee Low
Elizabeth S. Sattely

item.title: A Milky Way-like barred spiral galaxy at a redshift of 3
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06636-x

We report observations of ceers-2112 that show that this galaxy, at a redshift of 3, unexpectedly has a barred spiral structure.
item.dc:title: A Milky Way-like barred spiral galaxy at a redshift of 3

item.title: The power and potential of mitochondria transfer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06537-z

The mechanisms by which mitochondria are transferred between cells and how intercellular mitochondria transfer regulates physiological processes and disease pathogenesis are discussed.
item.dc:title: The power and potential of mitochondria transfer
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Borcherding
Jonathan R. Brestoff

item.title: TNRC18 engages H3K9me3 to mediate silencing of endogenous retrotransposons
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06688-z

Trinucleotide-repeat-containing 18 (TNRC18), which has poorly understood functions, is now identified as an H3K9me3-specific reader that silences endogenous retroviruses.
item.dc:title: TNRC18 engages H3K9me3 to mediate silencing of endogenous retrotransposons
item.dc:creator: Shuai Zhao
Jiuwei Lu
Bo Pan
Huitao Fan

Gang Greg Wang

item.title: Preserved neural dynamics across animals performing similar behaviour
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06714-0

Recordings of neural populations from motor cortex and striatum spanning monkeys and mice demonstrate that neural dynamics in individuals from the same species are preserved when they perform similar behaviour.
item.dc:title: Preserved neural dynamics across animals performing similar behaviour
item.dc:creator: Mostafa Safaie
Joanna C. Chang
Junchol Park
Lee E. Miller
Joshua T. Dudman
Matthew G. Perich
Juan A. Gallego

item.title: Functional genomics and systems biology in human neuroscience
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06686-1

Technical developments and large collaborative research networks in neurogenomics promise rapid progress in neuroscience, but translation of results from model systems to human brains is limited by sample availability, technical challenges and ethical issues.
item.dc:title: Functional genomics and systems biology in human neuroscience
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Konopka
Aparna Bhaduri

item.title: Predicting crystal form stability under real-world conditions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06587-3

Accuracy of free-energy calculations can be improved by constructing an experimental benchmark for solid–solid free-energy differences, quantifying statistical errors for the computed free energies and placing both hydrate and anhydrate crystal structures on the same energy landscape.
item.dc:title: Predicting crystal form stability under real-world conditions
item.dc:creator: Dzmitry Firaha

item.title: An evolutionary continuum from nucleated dwarf galaxies to star clusters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06650-z

In the Virgo galaxy cluster, we identified a continuum of objects that maps the morphological transition between nucleated dwarf galaxies and ultra-compact dwarf galaxies (UCDs), providing evidence for the formation of UCDs through tidal stripping of ancient dwarf galaxies.
item.dc:title: An evolutionary continuum from nucleated dwarf galaxies to star clusters
item.dc:creator: Kaixiang Wang

item.title: Aspartate all-in-one doping strategy enables efficient all-perovskite tandems
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06707-z

AspCl doping in Sn–Pb perovskite solar cells improves their performance and stability.
item.dc:title: Aspartate all-in-one doping strategy enables efficient all-perovskite tandems
item.dc:creator: Shun Zhou
Shiqiang Fu

item.title: Functional composites by programming entropy-driven nanosheet growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06660-x

Following a micro-then-nano growth sequence to fabricate composites that are blends of block-copolymer-based supramolecules, small molecules and nanoparticles shows that high-performance barrier materials can be manufactured by means of entropy-driven assembly.
item.dc:title: Functional composites by programming entropy-driven nanosheet growth

item.title: Autoantibodies against type I IFNs in humans with alternative NF-κB pathway deficiency
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06717-x

Inborn errors of the alternative NF-κB pathway in humans impair the development of AIRE-expressing medullary thymic epithelial cells, thereby underlying the production of autoantibodies against type I IFNs and predisposition to viral diseases
item.dc:title: Autoantibodies against type I IFNs in humans with alternative NF-κB pathway deficiency

item.title: Revising the global biogeography of annual and perennial plants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06644-x

The prevalence of annual plants worldwide rises in response to hot-dry summers, year-to-year variations, and disturbances, potentially impacting the future of ecosystem services provided by perennials.
item.dc:title: Revising the global biogeography of annual and perennial plants
item.dc:creator: Tyler Poppenwimer
Itay Mayrose
Niv DeMalach

item.title: Deconstruction of rheumatoid arthritis synovium defines inflammatory subtypes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06708-y

Single-cell transcriptomic and proteomic data from synovial tissue from individuals with rheumatoid arthritis classify patients into groups based on abundance of cell states that can provide insights into pathology and predict individual treatment responses.
item.dc:title: Deconstruction of rheumatoid arthritis synovium defines inflammatory subtypes
item.dc:creator: Fan Zhang

item.title: China must draw on internal research strength
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03445-0

The domestic pool of talent is deep, but international links are still crucial for maintaining the country’s role in the search for global solutions.
item.dc:title: China must draw on internal research strength
item.dc:creator: Cong Cao

item.title: Daily briefing: Biggest fossil-fuel-producing countries plan to drill more than ever
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03520-6

Countries including the United States, Canada, Russia and Saudi Arabia have plans that will bust our carbon budget more than twice over. Plus, treatments for dengue, and a rollicking folk history of fundamental physics.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Biggest fossil-fuel-producing countries plan to drill more than ever
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Synthetic drug kills fungi but spares kidney cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03358-y

Amphotericin B is a clinically vital antifungal drug, but it has high renal toxicity. The compound kills cells by forming sponge-like aggregates on the cell surface that remove molecules called sterols from the cell membrane. High-resolution structures of these sterol sponges guided rational development and synthesis of a new class of antifungals that are better for renal health.
item.dc:title: Synthetic drug kills fungi but spares kidney cells

item.title: United States and India are becoming science partners of choice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03443-2

But collaborations are still hampered by bureaucracy and underfunding.
item.dc:title: United States and India are becoming science partners of choice
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Engineered yeast breaks new record: a genome with over 50% synthetic DNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03495-4

Highly edited strain survives and replicates despite containing 7.5 artificial chromosomes.
item.dc:title: Engineered yeast breaks new record: a genome with over 50% synthetic DNA
item.dc:creator: Katherine Bourzac

item.title: How Paris is becoming a happy home for health-technology start-up companies
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03490-9

A long-term investment plan is helping the French capital to attract talent.
item.dc:title: How Paris is becoming a happy home for health-technology start-up companies
item.dc:creator: Nic Fleming

item.title: These incredible images are the first from dark-energy telescope Euclid
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03498-1

A spiral galaxy and the Horsehead Nebula are among the first pictures released by ESA’s Universe-mapping observatory.
item.dc:title: These incredible images are the first from dark-energy telescope Euclid
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Helium droplets help to visualize the start of ion solvation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02950-6

The number of helium atoms that gradually bind to a single sodium ion at the surface of a liquid helium nanodroplet has been measured as a function of time, as has the amount of energy that dissipates during this process. These findings provide a much-needed glimpse of the early steps of ion solvation.
item.dc:title: Helium droplets help to visualize the start of ion solvation

item.title: Talent & Culture
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03439-y

Family reunited.
item.dc:title: Talent & Culture
item.dc:creator: Timothy Quinn

item.title: Denmark puts its money where its life-sciences strategy is
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03446-z

Building on the success of blockbuster drugs, the country’s focus on reinvestment is feeding a stream of discovery.
item.dc:title: Denmark puts its money where its life-sciences strategy is
item.dc:creator: Bianca Nogrady

item.title: Flat bands find another dimension for exotic physical phases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03286-x

Experiments reveal flat bands in the relationship between the energy and the momentum of electrons in a 3D solid. Such behaviour is indicative of unusual physical phenomena, and has previously been seen only in 2D materials.
item.dc:title: Flat bands find another dimension for exotic physical phases
item.dc:creator: Xingjiang Zhou

item.title: Four science stars on the fast-track to impact
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03444-1

With the world at their feet, these prolific young researchers are making their mark.
item.dc:title: Four science stars on the fast-track to impact
item.dc:creator: Sandy Ong
Chris Woolston

item.title: Daily briefing: Surprising findings from India’s Moon mission
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02878-x

India’s Chandrayaan-3 mission has measured the Moon’s surface temperature and recorded a suspected moonquake. Plus, scientific sleuths spot telltale signs of undeclared ChatGPT in papers and the extraordinary story of how the SDGs came to be.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Surprising findings from India’s Moon mission
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Why a climate researcher pushed the limits of low-carbon travel — and his employer’s patience
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03496-3

A refusal to fly to Papua New Guinea for fieldwork took Gianluca Grimalda the long way across 22,000 kilometres and 12 countries.
item.dc:title: Why a climate researcher pushed the limits of low-carbon travel — and his employer’s patience
item.dc:creator: Christine Ro

item.title: Why postdocs need entrepreneurship training
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03411-w

Landing tenure is a pipe dream for most postdoctoral researchers. They need business skills to help them thrive outside academia.
item.dc:title: Why postdocs need entrepreneurship training
item.dc:creator: Muhammad Shehryar Khan
Jeffrey Casello

item.title: How to tame a toxic yet life-saving antifungal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03499-0

Researchers modify drug to prevent kidney damage, and the mystery of the phosphorus at the Milky Way’s edge.
item.dc:title: How to tame a toxic yet life-saving antifungal
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Thompson
Nick Petrić Howe

item.title: Brain and body are more intertwined than we knew
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03435-2

A host of disorders once thought to be nothing to do with the brain are, in fact, tightly coupled to nervous-system activity.
item.dc:title: Brain and body are more intertwined than we knew

item.title: Ultra-compact oddities are galaxies stripped of stars
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03275-0

Observations have shown that some dwarf galaxies lose their stars through interactions with more massive galaxies. The dense nuclei that remain are ultra-compact dwarf galaxies, the origin of which has long been a subject of debate.
item.dc:title: Ultra-compact oddities are galaxies stripped of stars
item.dc:creator: Katja Fahrion

item.title: The rise of brain-reading technology: what you need to know
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 08 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03423-6

As implanted devices and commercial headsets advance, what will the real-world impacts be?
item.dc:title: The rise of brain-reading technology: what you need to know
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: How AI could lead to a better understanding of the brain
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03426-3

Early machine-learning systems were inspired by neural networks — now AI might allow neuroscientists to get to grips with the brain’s unique complexities.
item.dc:title: How AI could lead to a better understanding of the brain
item.dc:creator: Viren Jain

item.title: Nature retracts controversial superconductivity paper by embattled physicist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03398-4

This is the third high-profile retraction for Ranga Dias. Researchers worry the controversy is damaging the field’s reputation.
item.dc:title: Nature retracts controversial superconductivity paper by embattled physicist
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: The ‘brazen’ science that paved the way for the Higgs boson (and a lot more)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 November 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-03424-5

Fundamental physics has progressed in leaps and bounds in the past century — driven by strong characters and often a complete disregard for health and safety, as a spirited history shows.
item.dc:title: The ‘brazen’ science that paved the way for the Higgs boson (and a lot more)
item.dc:creator: Tara Shears
